The form asks people to select one of the twenty-eight countries that make up the European Union, as well as Iceland, Liechtenstein, Norway, and Switzerland.<ref>{{cite web|title=Search Removal Request Under Data Protection Law in Europe|url=https://support.google.com/legal/contact/lr_eudpa?product=websearch|website=Google|accessdate=22 May 2015}}</ref> "The form allows an individual or someone representing an individual to put in a request" for the removal of any URLs believed to be a violation of the individual's privacy.<ref name= "Sullivan D">{{cite news|last1=Sullivan|first1=Danny|title=How Google's New 'Right to be Forgotten' Form Works: An Explainer|url=http://searchengineland.com/google-right-to-be-forgotten-form-192837|accessdate=22 May 2015|publisher=Search Engine Land|date=30 May 2014}}</ref> Regardless of who is submitting the form, some form of photo identification of the person the form is being submitted for must be presented. The purpose of this is to provide proof that the person for whom the request is being made does in fact approve.
The form allows people to submit the name they would like search results removed for. However, it only allows for the submission of one name, which some view as one of its flaws.<ref name= "Sullivan D" /> For example, if someone known as both "Lawrence Smith" and "Larry Smith" were to submit a form for the removal of search results for his name, he would only be allowed to indicate one of these names on the form.<ref name= "Sullivan D" /> Many people view it as inconvenient and believe it is a problem that Google should be able to easily fix.<ref name= "Sullivan D" />
If Google refuses a request to delink material, Europeans can appeal to their local data protection agency.<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2014/jun/26/google-removing-right-to-be-forgotten-links|title = Google removing 'right to be forgotten' search links in Europe|website = The Guardian|last = Arthur|first = Charles}}</ref> As of May 2015, the British Data Protection Agency had treated 184 such complaints, and overturned Google's decision in about a quarter of those.<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.theregister.co.uk/2015/05/14/ico_google_clash_right_to_be_forgotten/|title = 'Right to be forgotten' festers as ICO and Google come to blows|website = The Register|last = Martin|first = Alexander J.}}</ref> If Google objects to a Data Protection Agency decision, it can face legal action.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.thetimes.co.uk/tto/technology/internet/article4438460.ece|title = Google could face legal action over 'right to be forgotten' rejections|website = The Times|last = Dean|first = James}}</ref>
In July 2014, in the early stages of Google's effort to comply with the court ruling, legal experts questioned whether Google's widely publicised delistings of a number of news articles violated the UK and EU [[Data Protection Directive]], since in implementing the Directive, Google is required to weigh the damage to the person making the request against any public interest in the information being available.<ref name="whydoit">{{cite news |url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2014/07/04/google_peston_bbc_delisting_not_compliant_w_public_interest_law_says_expert/ |title=Google de-listing of BBC article 'broke UK and Euro public interest laws' - So WHY do it? |last1=Orlowski |first1=Andrew |date=4 July 2014 |website=www.theregister.co.uk |publisher=The Register |accessdate=4 July 2014}}</ref> Google indeed acknowledged that some of its search result removals, affecting articles that were of public interest, were incorrect, and reinstated the links a week later.<ref name="Arthur">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2014/jul/04/what-is-google-deleting-under-the-right-to-be-forgotten-and-why|last=Arthur|first=Charles|title=What is Google deleting under the 'right to be forgotten' - and why? What if there were a page on a 'revenge porn' site about you - would you want to use Google's 'right to be forgotten' to get it taken out of search?|work=The Guardian|date=4 July 2014|accessdate=11 August 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2014/jul/10/right-to-be-forgotten-european-ruling-google-debate|title=We need to talk about the right to be forgotten|author=David Drummond|work=the Guardian}}</ref> Commentators like Charles Arthur, technology editor of ''The Guardian'', and Andrew Orlowski of ''The Register'' noted that Google is not required to comply with removal requests at all, as it can refer requests to the information commissioner in the relevant country for a decision weighing the respective merits of public interest and individual rights.<ref name="Arthur" /><ref name="whydoit" /><ref name="grasp">{{cite news|url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2014/06/17/for_mon_how_google_plans_to_torpedo_your_privacy_rights/|title=Slippery Google greases up, aims to squirm out of EU privacy grasp. Will the huge advertising firm manage to spin its way free of the law? |last1=Orlowski |first1=Andrew |date=17 June 2014 |website=www.theregister.co.uk |publisher=The Register |accessdate=11 August 2014}}</ref>
Google notifies websites that have URLs delinked, and the BBC and other news organizations have published lists of delinked articles. Complainants have been named in news commentary regarding those delinkings. In August 2015 the British Data Protection Agency issued an enforcement action requiring Google to delink some of these more recent articles from searches for a complainant's name, after Google refused to do so.<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2015/aug/20/google-ordered-to-remove-links-to-stories-about-right-to-be-forgotten-removals|title = Google ordered to remove links to 'right to be forgotten' removal stories|website = The Guardian|last = Gibbs|first = Samuel}}</ref> Google complied with the request.<ref name=":0" /> Some academics have criticized news organizations and Google for their behavior.<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2015/jul/01/bbc-wrong-right-to-be-forgotten|title = Why the BBC is wrong to republish 'right to be forgotten' links|website = The Guardian|last = Powles|first = Julia}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url = http://theconversation.com/privacy-watchdog-takes-first-step-against-those-undermining-right-to-be-forgotten-46495|title = Privacy watchdog takes first step against those undermining right to be forgotten|website = The Conversation|last = Boiten|first = Eerke}}</ref>
As of May 2014, Google has removed 1,390,838 URLs.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web | url = http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sciencetech/article-3140534/Could-right-forgotten-automated-Oblivion-software-help-Google-remove-hundreds-people-web-seconds.html | title = Oblivion handles hundreds of right to be forgotten demands in SECONDS | website = Mail Online | access-date = 2016-02-29 }}</ref> From a gathering of which websites had the most amount of links removed, Facebook won with a total of 11,973 URLs removed. [[YouTube]] had 5,999 removed, [[Google Groups]] had 7,246 removed, and [[Twitter]] had 4,588 removed.<ref name=":1" /> Though Facebook had the largest number of deleted URLs, there were other received requests that were not granted deletion. While Google does evaluate millions of URLs that have been requested to be removed, the ultimate decision must be made by a human "because the variables, including public interest claims, needs to be handled on a case-by-case basis".<ref name=":1" /> However, it is to be kept in mind that internet users can still find removed information somewhat easily, just not through European Google search engines.
In July 2015, Google accidentally revealed data on delinkings that "shows 95% of Google privacy requests are from citizens out to protect personal and private information – not criminals, politicians and public figures."<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2015/jul/14/google-accidentally-reveals-right-to-be-forgotten-requests|title = Google accidentally reveals data on 'right to be forgotten' requests|website = The Guardian|last = Tippmann|first = Sylvia|first2 = Julia|last2 = Powles}}</ref>
This data leak caused serious social consequences for Google as the public expressed their outrage and fear over the information that was recently made public. Though only 5% of requests were made by criminals, politicians, and public figures, the content removed was what sparked the most fear.<ref name=":2">{{Cite news | url = https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2015/jul/14/google-accidentally-reveals-right-to-be-forgotten-requests | title = Google accidentally reveals data on 'right to be forgotten' requests | last = Tippmann | first = Sylvia | date = 2015-07-14 | last2 = Powles | first2 = Julia | newspaper = The Guardian | language = en-GB | issn = 0261-3077 | access-date = 2016-02-29 }}</ref> In particular, one request for data removal was from a British doctor requesting to have 50 links removed on past botched medical procedures. Google agreed to remove three search results containing his personal information.<ref name=":2" /> The public voiced their outrage stating that removing such information can be used for manipulation and could lead to innocent people making uninformed decisions. Google responded to the public outrage by saying that when removing content they consider both the right of the individual and public interest.<ref name=":2" />
The European Union has been pushing for the delinkings requested by EU citizens to be implemented by Google not just in European versions of Google (as in google.co.uk, google.fr, etc.), but on google.com and other international subdomains. Regulators want delinkings to be implemented so that the law cannot be circumvented in any way. Google has refused the French Data Protection Agency's demand to apply the right internationally.<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2015/jul/30/google-rejects-france-expand-right-to-be-forgotten-worldwide|title = Google says non to French demand to expand right to be forgotten worldwide|website = The Guardian|last = Hern|first = Alex}}</ref> Due in part to their refusal to comply with the recommendation of the privacy regulating board Google has become the subject of a four-year-long antitrust investigation by the European Commission.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cnet.com/news/eu-wants-right-to-be-forgotten-applied-globally/|title=EU wants 'right to be forgotten' applied globally|publisher=CBS Interactive|work=CNET}}</ref> In September 2015, the French Data Protection Agency dismissed Google's appeal.<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2015/sep/21/french-google-right-to-be-forgotten-appeal|title = French data regulator rejects Google's right-to-be-forgotten appeal|date = 21 September 2015|accessdate = 23 September 2015|website = The Guardian|last = Gibbs|first = Samuel}}</ref>
As of September 2015, the most delinked site is ''www.facebook.com''. Three of Google's own sites, ''groups.google.com'', ''plus.google.com'' and ''www.youtube.com'' are among the ten most delinked sites.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url = https://www.google.com/transparencyreport/removals/europeprivacy/?hl=en|title = Transparency Report. European privacy requests for search removals|accessdate = 10 September 2015|website = Google}}</ref> In addition to Google, Yahoo and Bing have also put up forms for making delinking requests.
===Spain=== In May 2014, the [[European Court of Justice]] ruled against [[Google]] in ''[[Google v González|Costeja]]'', a case brought by a Spanish man, Mario Costeja González, who requested the removal of a link to a digitized 1998 article in ''La Vanguardia'' newspaper about an auction for his foreclosed home, for a debt that he had subsequently paid.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.wired.co.uk/news/archive/2014-05/15/google-vs-spain | title=What we can salvage from 'right to be forgotten' ruling | publisher=Wired.co.uk | date=15 May 2014 | accessdate=16 May 2014 | author=Julia Powles}}</ref> He initially attempted to have the article removed by complaining to the [[Spanish Agency of data protection]], which rejected the claim on the grounds that it was lawful and accurate, but accepted a complaint against Google and asked Google to remove the results.<ref>{{cite web|last=Solon|first=Olivia|title=People have the right to be forgotten, rules EU court|url=https://www.wired.co.uk/news/archive/2014-05/13/right-to-be-forgotten-ruling|work=Wired.co.uk|publisher=Conde Nast Digital|accessdate=13 May 2014|date=13 May 2014}}</ref> Google sued in the [[Audiencia Nacional (Spain)|Spanish ''Audiencia Nacional'']] (National High Court) which referred a series of questions to the European Court of Justice.<ref>{{cite press release |author=[[European Court of Justice]] |title=Judgment of the Court of Justice in Case C-131/12: An internet search engine operator is responsible for the processing that it carries out of personal data which appear on web pages published by third parties |url=http://curia.europa.eu/jcms/jcms/P_127116/ |location=Luxembourg |publisher= |agency= |date=13 May 2014 |accessdate=13 May 2014}}</ref> The court ruled in ''Costeja'' that search engines are responsible for the content they point to and thus, Google was required to comply with EU data privacy laws.<ref>{{cite web|title=EU court backs 'right to be forgotten' in Google case|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-27388289|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=13 May 2014|date=13 May 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=EU court rules Google must tweak search results in test of 'right to be forgotten'|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/eu-court-google-must-tweak-search-results-right-to-be-forgotten/|publisher=CBS News|accessdate=13 May 2014|date=13 May 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/05/14/technology/google-should-erase-web-links-to-some-personal-data-europes-highest-court-says.html |title=European Court Lets Users Erase Records on Web |newspaper=[[New York Times]] |date=13 May 2014|accessdate= 14 August 2014|author=David Streitfeld}}</ref> On its first day of compliance only (May 30, 2014), Google received 12,000 requests to have personal details removed from its search engine.<ref>{{cite news|title=Removal of Google personal information could become work intensive|url=http://www.europenews.net/index.php/sid/222490797/scat/88176adfdf246af5/ht/Removal-of-Google-personal-information-could-become-work-intensive|accessdate=2 June 2014|publisher=Europe News.Net}}</ref>
===Germany=== On October 27, 2009, lawyers for [[Wolfgang Werlé]] who—together with Manfred Lauber—was convicted of murdering [[Walter Sedlmayr]] sent the [[Wikimedia Foundation]] a [[cease and desist]] letter requesting that Werlé's name be removed from the English language [[Wikipedia]] article [[Walter Sedlmayr]], citing a 1973 [[Federal Constitutional Court]] decision that allows the suppression of a criminal's name in news accounts once he is released from custody.<ref name="nyt">{{cite news |title=Two German Killers Demanding Anonymity Sue Wikipedia's Parent |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/11/13/us/13wiki.html |quote=Wolfgang Werlé and Manfred Lauber became infamous for killing a German actor in 1990. Now they are suing to force Wikipedia to forget them. |work=[[New York Times]] |date=November 12, 2009 |accessdate=2009-11-13 |first=John |last=Schwartz}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.wired.com/threatlevel/2009/11/wikipedia_murder |title=Convicted Murderer Sues Wikipedia, Demands Removal of His Name |first=David |last=Kravets |work=[[Wired News]] |quote=Wikipedia is under a censorship attack by a convicted murderer who is invoking Germany's privacy laws in a bid to remove references to his killing of a Bavarian actor in 1990. |date=November 11, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{Citation |year=2009 |title=Cease and Desist letter |work=[[Wired News]] |url=https://www.wired.com/images_blogs/threatlevel/2009/11/stopp.pdf |format=PDF}}</ref> Previously, Alexander H. Stopp, attorney for Werlé and Lauber, had won a default judgment in German court, on behalf of Lauber, against the Wikimedia Foundation.<ref name="nyt"/> According to the [[Electronic Frontier Foundation]], Werlé's lawyers also challenged an Internet service provider in Austria which published the names of the convicted killers.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2009/11/12/wikipedia_sued_by_convicted_murderer |title=Wikipedia sued for publishing convicted murderer's name |work=[[The Register]]}}</ref>
Wikimedia is based in the United States, where the First Amendment protects [[Freedom of speech in the United States|freedom of speech]] and [[Freedom of the press in the United States|freedom of the press]]. In Germany, the law seeks to protect the name and likenesses of private persons from unwanted publicity.<ref>{{cite news |title = Convicted Murderer To Wikipedia: Shhh! |author=[[Jennifer Granick]] | quote=Who killed Sedlmayr? Its [sic] a matter of public record, but if one of the men and his German law firm gets their way, Wikipedia (and EFF) will not be allowed to tell you. A few days ago, the online encyclopedia received a cease and desist letter from one of the convicts—represented by the aptly named German law firm Stopp and Stopp—demanding that the perpetrator's name be taken off of the Sedlmayr article page. | publisher=[[Electronic Frontier Foundation]] |date=10 November 2009 |url=https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2009/11/murderer-wikipedia-shhh}}</ref> On January 18, 2008, a court in [[Hamburg]] supported the personality rights of Werlé, which under German law includes removing his name from archive coverage of the case.<ref>{{cite news|title=Abwägung bei einem Unterlassungsanspruch zwischen dem Recht auf freie Meinungsäußerung und dem Persönlichkeitsrecht (Resozialisierung) bei elektronischen Pressearchiven einen Mordfall betreffend |author=|publisher=Hamburger Justiz|date=18 January 2008|accessdate=January 13, 2012 | language=German|url=http://www.landesrecht.hamburg.de/jportal/portal/page/bshaprod.psml;jsessionid=D0EE59E4F4B727BF37EAB3766448FAB8.jpj4?showdoccase=1&doc.id=JURE080001422}}</ref>
On November 12, 2009, ''[[The New York Times]]'' reported that Wolfgang Werlé had a case pending against the [[Wikimedia Foundation]] in a German court. The editors of the German-language Wikipedia [[:de:Walter Sedlmayr|article about Sedlmayr]] removed the names of the murderers,<ref name="nyt"/> which have since then been restored to the article. ''[[The Guardian]]'' observed that the lawsuit has led to the [[Streisand effect]], an upsurge in publicity for the case resulting from the legal action.<ref>{{cite news |first=Charles |last=Arthur |title=Wikipedia sued by German killers in privacy claim |url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2009/nov/13/wikipedia-sued-privacy-claim |quote= |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=November 13, 2009 |accessdate=2009-11-15 |location=London}}</ref>
On December 15, 2009, the German [[Federal Court of Justice of Germany|Federal Court of Justice]] (Bundesgerichtshof) in [[Karlsruhe]] ruled that German websites do not have to check their archives in order to provide permanent protection of personality rights for convicted criminals. The case occurred after the names of the brothers were found on the website of [[Deutschlandradio]], in an archive article dating from July 2000.<ref>{{cite news|title=Vor 10 Jahren – Walter Sedlmayr ermordet|language=German|work=[[Deutschlandradio]]|date= 14 July 2000|url= http://www.dradio.de/dlr/sendungen/kalender/127148/|accessdate = 2009-12-17}}</ref> The presiding judge Gregor Galke stated "This is not a blank check", and pointed out that the right to rehabilitation of offenders had been taken into consideration.<ref>{{cite news|title=Namen der Sedlmayr-Mörder bleiben online|work=[[Süddeutsche Zeitung]] |url=http://www.sueddeutsche.de/computer/410/497712/text/|accessdate=2009-12-15}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |authorlink=avs/dpa |title=BGH-Urteil – Keine ständige Kontrolle von Online-Archiven |url=http://www.focus.de/digital/internet/bgh-urteil-keine-staendige-kontrolle-von-online-archiven_aid_463464.html |publisher=Focus |language=German|date=December 15, 2009 |accessdate=2012-01-13}}</ref>
===Argentina=== Argentina has seen law suits by [[celebrities]] against [[Google]] and [[Yahoo!]] in which the plaintiffs demand the removal of certain search results, and require removal of links to photographs.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.infotechnology.com/internet/La-Justicia-argentina-sobreseyo-a-Adriana-Norea-presidente-de-Google.hmtl-20120604-0005.html |title=La Justicia Argentina Sobreseyó a Adriana Noreña, Directora General de Google |publisher=Infotechnology.com |date=2012-09-21 |accessdate=2014-08-09}}</ref> One case, brought by artist [[Virginia da Cunha]], involved photographs which had originally been taken with her permission and uploaded with her permission, however she alleged that the search results improperly associated her photographs with pornography.<ref>Carter, Edward L. "Argentina's Right to Be Forgotten." Emory International Law Review. 27 (2013): pg 23.</ref> De Cunha's case achieved initial success resulting in Argentine search engines not showing images of the particular celebrity, however this decision is on appeal.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.buenosairesherald.com/article/139989/ |title='Search engines not responsible for content' |publisher=BuenosAiresHerald.com |date=2013-09-05 |accessdate=2014-08-09}}</ref>
Virginia Simari, the judge in favor of De Cunha, stated that people have the right to control their image and avert others from "capturing, reproducing, broadcasting, or publishing one's image without permission."<ref name="Carter">{{Cite web|url=http://law.emory.edu/eilr/content/volume-27/issue-1/recent-developments/argentinas-right-to-be-forgotten.html|title=Argentina's Right to be Forgotten|last=Carter|first=Edward|date=|website=Emory International Law Review|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> In addition, Simari used a treatise written by Julio César Rivera, a Buenos Aires lawyer, author, and law professor "the right to control one's personal data includes the right to prevent others from using one's image."<ref name="Carter"/> Since the 1990s Argentina has also been a part of the habeas data movement in which they "adopted a constitutional provision that is part freedom-of-government-information law and part data privacy law."<ref name="Carter"/> However, their version is known as amparo. Article 43<ref name="Carter"/> explains the version:
"Any person shall file this action to obtain information on the data about himself and their purpose, registered in public records or databases, or in private ones intended to supply information; and in case of false data or discrimination, this action may be filed to request the suppression, rectification, confidentiality or updating of said data."<ref name="Carter"/>
Argentina's efforts to protect their people's right to be forgotten has been called 'the most complete' because individuals are able to correct, delete, or update information about themselves. Overall, their information is bound to remain confidential.
===United States=== Consideration of the right to be forgotten can be seen in US case law, specifically in ''Melvin v. Reid'', and in ''Sidis v. FR Publishing Corp.''<ref>Melvin v. Reid, 112 Cal.App. 285, 297 P. 91 (1931); Sidis v F-R Publishing Corporation 311 U.S. 711 61 S. Ct. 393 85 L. Ed. 462 1940 U.S.</ref>
In ''Melvin v. Reid'' (1931), an ex-prostitute was charged with murder and then acquitted; she subsequently tried to assume a quiet and anonymous place in society. However, the 1925 film ''[[The Red Kimono]]'' revealed her history, and she successfully sued the producer.<ref>Melvin v. Reid, 112 Cal.App. 285, 297 P. 91 (1931)</ref><ref>{{cite book |chapter=The Red {{sic|Kimono}}: The Saga of Gabriel Darley Melvin |last=Friedman |first=Lawrence Meir |title=Guarding Life's Dark Secrets: Legal and Social Controls over Reputation, Propriety, and Privacy |location= |publisher=Stanford University Press |edition= |year=2007 |pages=217–225 |isbn=978-0-8047-5739-3 }}</ref> The court reasoned that "any person living a life of rectitude has that right to happiness which includes a freedom from unnecessary attacks on his character, social standing or reputation."<ref>Melvin v. Reid, 112 Cal.App. 285, 297 P. 91 (1931) at 852-853</ref>
In ''Sidis v. FR Publishing Corp.'' (1940), the plaintiff, [[William James Sidis]], was a former [[child prodigy]] who wished to spend his adult life quietly, without recognition; however, this was disrupted by an article in ''[[The New Yorker]]''.<ref name="ReferenceA">Sidis v F-R Publishing Corporation 311 U.S. 711 61 S. Ct. 393 85 L. Ed. 462 1940 U.S.</ref> The court held here that there were limits to the right to control one's life and facts about oneself, and held that there is social value in published facts, and that a person cannot ignore their celebrity status merely because they want to.<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
There is opposition to further recognition of the right to be forgotten in the United States as commentators argue that it will contravene the right to [[freedom of speech]] and freedom of expression, or will constitute [[censorship]], thus potentially breaching peoples' constitutionally protected right to freedom of expression in the [[United States Constitution]].<ref name="theatlantic1">{{cite web|last=Hendel |first=John |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/technology/archive/2012/01/why-journalists-shouldnt-fear-europes-right-to-be-forgotten/251955/ |title=Why Journalists Shouldn't Fear Europe's 'Right to be Forgotten' |work=[[The Atlantic]] |date=2012-01-25 |accessdate=2014-08-09}}</ref> These criticisms are consistent with the proposal that the only information that can be removed by user's request is content that they themselves uploaded.{{clarify|date=July 2017}}<ref name="theatlantic1"/><ref name="walker">Walker, Robert K. "The Right to be forgotten." 64 Hastings Law Journal 257, 2012. Pg 257.</ref>
In a June 2014 opinion piece in Forbes, columnist Joseph Steinberg noted that "many privacy protections that Americans believe that they enjoy – even some guaranteed by law – have, in fact, been eroded or even obliterated by technological advances." Steinberg, in explaining the need for legislation guaranteeing the "right to be forgotten", noted that existing laws that require adverse information to be removed from credit reports after a period of time, and that allow the sealing or expunging of criminals records, are effectively undermined by the ability of prospective lenders or employers to forever find the removed information in a matter of seconds by doing a web search.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/josephsteinberg/2014/06/02/your-privacy-is-now-at-risk-from-search-engines-even-if-the-law-says-otherwise/ |author=Joseph Steinberg |authorlink=Joseph Steinberg |title=Your Privacy Is Now At Risk From Search Engines -- Even If The Law Says Otherwise |publisher=Forbes |date=2014-06-02 |accessdate=2014-06-03}}</ref>
On March 11, 2015, [[Intelligence Squared|Intelligence Squared US]], an organization that stages [[Debate#Oxford-style debating|Oxford-Style debates]], held an event centered on the question, "Should the U.S. adopt the 'Right to be Forgotten' online?" The side against the motion won with a 56% majority of the voting audience.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://intelligencesquaredus.org/debates/past-debates/item/1252-the-u-s-should-adopt-the-right-to-be-forgotten-online|title=The U.S. Should Adopt the 'Right to Be Forgotten' Online|work=intelligencesquaredus.org}}</ref>
While opinions among experts are divided in the U.S., one survey indicated that 9 in 10 Americans want some form of the right to be forgotten.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.adweek.com/prnewser/hey-google-9-in-10-americans-want-the-right-to-be-forgotten/111218|title = Hey Google: 9 in 10 Americans Want the 'Right to Be Forgotten'|website = Adweek|last = Coffee|first = Patrick}}</ref> The consumer rights organization [[Consumer Watchdog]] has filed a complaint with the Federal Trade Commission for Americans to obtain the right as well.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.nbcnews.com/tech/internet/consumer-watchdog-google-should-extend-right-be-forgotten-u-s-n388131|title = Consumer Watchdog: Google Should Extend 'Right To Be Forgotten' to U.S.|website = NBC News|last = Eng|first = James}}</ref>
In March 2017, [[State of New York|New York]] state senator [[Tony Avella]] and assemblyman [[David Weprin]] introduced a bill proposing that individuals be allowed to require search engines and online speakers to remove information that is "inaccurate", "irrelevant", "inadequate", or "excessive", that is "no longer material to current public debate or discourse" and is causing demonstrable harm to the subject.<ref name="wp-nybill">{{cite web|title=N.Y. bill would require people to remove 'inaccurate,' 'irrelevant,' 'inadequate' or 'excessive' statements about others|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/volokh-conspiracy/wp/2017/03/15/n-y-bill-would-require-people-to-remove-inaccurate-irrelevant-inadequate-or-excessive-statements-about-others/|website=Washington Post|accessdate=17 March 2017}}</ref>
=== India === In April 2016, the [[Delhi High Court]] began to examine the issue after a Delhi banker requested to have his personal details removed from search results following a marital dispute.<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/Delhi-banker-seeks-right-to-be-forgotten-online/articleshow/52060003.cms|title=Delhi banker seeks 'right to be forgotten' online - Times of India|website=The Times of India|access-date=2016-05-23}}</ref> In this case, due to the dispute being settled, the banker's request is valid.<ref name=":4" /> The High Court has asked for a reply from Google and other search engine companies by September 19, upon which the court will continue to investigate the issue.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.catchnews.com/tech-news/what-is-the-right-to-be-forgotten-and-how-it-will-affect-you-1462532182.html|title=What is the Right to be Forgotten and how it could affect you?|website=CatchNews.com|access-date=2016-05-23}}</ref>
In January 2017 the [[Karnataka High Court]] upheld the right to be forgotten, in a case involving a woman who originally went to court in order to get a marriage certificate annulled, claiming to have never been married to the man on the certificate.<ref name=":7">{{Cite news|url=http://www.livelaw.in/first-indian-court-upholds-right-forgotten-read-order/|title=In A First An Indian Court Upholds The 'Right To Be Forgotten' [Read Order] {{!}} Live Law|date=2017-02-03|work=Live Law|access-date=2017-03-03|language=en-US}}</ref> After the two parties came to an agreement, the woman's father wanted her name to be removed from search engines regarding criminal cases in the high court.<ref name=":7" /> The Karnataka High Court approved the father's request, stating that she had a right to be forgotten. According to the court, its ruling would align with western countries' decisions, which typically approve of the right to be forgotten when dealing with cases "involving women in general and highly sensitive cases involving rape or affecting the modesty and reputation of the person concerned."<ref name=":7" /> The woman in this specific case was worried that the search results would affect her standing with her husband, as well as her reputation in society.<ref name=":7" />
As of February 2017, the Delhi High Court is hearing a case involving a man requesting to have information regarding his mother and wife to be removed from a search engine.<ref name=":8">{{Cite news|url=http://www.firstpost.com/india/right-to-be-forgotten-how-a-prudent-karnataka-hc-judgment-could-pave-the-way-for-privacy-laws-in-india-3270938.html|title=Right to be forgotten: How a prudent Karnataka HC judgment could pave the way for privacy laws in India|date=2017-02-07|work=Firstpost|access-date=2017-03-03|language=en-US}}</ref> The man believes that having his name linked to the search is hindering his employment options.<ref name=":8" /> The Delhi High Court is still working on the case, along with the issue of whether or not a right to be forgotten should be a legal standard in India.<ref name=":8" /> Currently, there is no legal standard for the right to be forgotten, but if implemented, this would mean that citizens no longer need to file a case in order to request for information from search engines to be removed.<ref name=":8" /> This case could have significant impacts on the right to be forgotten and search engines in India.
=== South Korea === In May 2016, [[Korea Communications Commission|South Korea's Korea Communications Commission]] (KCC) announced citizens will be able to request search engines and website administrators to restrict their own postings from being publicly accessible.<ref name=":5">{{Cite web|url=http://www.bna.com/south-korea-releases-n57982070847/|title=South Korea Releases Right to Be Forgotten Guidance|website=www.bna.com|access-date=2016-05-23}}</ref> The KCC released "[http://src.bna.com/eBy Guidelines on the Right to Request Access Restrictions on Personal Internet Postings]", which will take effect in June 2016, which will not apply to third party contents.<ref name=":5" /> To the extent that the right to be forgotten concerns a data subject's right to limit the searchability of third party postings about him/her, the Guideline does not constitute a right to be forgotten.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.hani.co.kr/arti/economy/it/736858.html|title=방통위, '잊혀질 권리 가이드라인' 제정|date=2016-03-25|access-date=2016-09-18}}</ref> Also, as to the right to withdraw one's own posting, critics have noted that people have been able to delete their own postings before the Guideline as long as they have retained their login credentials, and that people who have misplaced their login credentials were permitted to retrieve or receive new ones.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://byline.network/2016/04/1-94/|title=[심재석의 입장] 방통위의 이상한 '잊혀질 권리 가이드라인'|last=심재석|date=2016-04-01|website=BYLINE NETWORK|access-date=2016-09-18}}</ref> The only services significantly affected by the Guideline are Wiki-type services where people's contributions make logical sense only in response to or in conjunction with one another's contributions and therefore the postings are made permanent part of the mass-created content, but KCC made sure that the Guideline applies to these services only when the posting identifies the authors.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://news.chosun.com/site/data/html_dir/2016/06/29/2016062902224.html|title='네이버 지식iN' 질문 글, 개인정보 남아 있을 때만 '잊혀질 권리' 적용|access-date=2016-09-18}}</ref>
The guidelines created by the KCC include that data subjects can remove content that includes the URL links, and any evidence consisting of personal information. The commission included different amendments to the guideline. This includes describing the Guidelines as a "minimum" and "preliminary"<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bna.com/south-korea-releases-n57982070847/|title=South Korea Releases Right to Be Forgotten Guidance|last=Lim|first=James|date=|website=Bloomberg BNA|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> precaution regarding privacy rights in vague areas of existing laws. The guideline encompasses foreign Internet companies that provide translation services for South Korean consumers. In order to have a person's information "forgotten" he or she has to go through a three step process:<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.mondaq.com/x/561018/IT+internet/Korea+Communications+Commission+Releases+Guidelines+On+The+Right+To+Be+Forgotten|title=Korea Communications Commission Releases Guidelines On "The Right to Be Forgotten"|last=Yulchon LLC|first=|date=|website=Mondaq|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> the issue posted with the URL, proof of ownership of the post, grounds for the request. There are restrictions on each step. When posting the URL, the web operator has the right to preserve the posting issue. The second being that if the post is relevant to public interest, web operators will process this request on the terms of relevance.
=== China === In May 2016, Chinese courts in Beijing determined citizens do not have the right to be forgotten when a judge ruled in favor of [[Baidu]] in a lawsuit over removing search results.<ref name=":6">{{Cite web|url=http://www.sixthtone.com/news/chinese-have-no-right-be-forgotten-court-rules|title=Chinese Have No Right to Be Forgotten, Court Rules|last=Tone|first=Sixth|date=2016-05-05|website=Sixth Tone|access-date=2016-05-23}}</ref> It was the first of such cases to be heard in Chinese court.<ref name=":6" /> In the suit, Ren Jiayu sued Chinese search engine Baidu over search results that associated him with a previous employer, Wuxi Taoshi Biotechnology.<ref name=":6" /> Ren argued that by posting the search results, Baidu had infringed upon his right of name and right of reputation, both protected under Chinese law.<ref name=":6" /> Because of these protections, Ren believed he had a right to be forgotten by removing these search results.<ref name=":6" /> The court ruled against Ren, claiming his name is a collection of common characters and as a result the search results were derived from relevant words.<ref name=":6" />
China has one of the longest histories as an entire nation, being over 2000 years of feudal society; their civil laws and personal rights have not been altered through legislative efforts. Nowhere in the country's civil agreement does it discuss the concept of "privacy", more specifically internet privacy, and the growing issue that citizens, "have the right to be forgotten" on the internet.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.victoria.ac.nz/law/research/publications/vuwlr/prev-issues/pdf/vol-36-2005/issue-3/jingchun.pdf|title=Protecting the Right to Privacy in China|last=Jingchun|first=Cao|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> There is no data protection authority or a specific state agency set in place to monitor the protection of citizens personal data. In China today, data protection is aimed at simply the consumer, as an individual. In contrast to the EU's right to privacy, which the individual is considered a "data subject", with the right to be protected.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.europarl.europa.eu/RegData/etudes/IDAN/2015/536472/IPOL_IDA%282015%29536472_EN.pdf|title=Policy Department Citizen's Right and Constitutional Affairs|last=Hert|first=Paul|last2=Papakonstantinou|first2=Vagelis|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Chinese legislation remains neutral, with slow progression towards the support of the "right to be forgotten". The topic has been debated for more than 10 years now, and continues to be a challenge. Small provisions have been implemented related to personal data processing, however they do not amount to a comprehensive data protection regime.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.europarl.europa.eu/RegData/etudes/IDAN/2015/536472/IPOL_IDA%282015%29536472_EN.pdf|title=Policy Department Citizen's Right and Constitutional Affairs|last=Hert|first=Paul|last2=Papakonstantinou|first2=Vagelis|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> There is no solid, common ground to be found on two fundamentally different systems: realistic, to Chinese laws that are already in place, and legalist, the steps it takes to change those laws, approaches that elicit a need for reification.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.europarl.europa.eu/RegData/etudes/IDAN/2015/536472/IPOL_IDA%282015%29536472_EN.pdf|title=Policy Department Citizen's Right and Constitutional Affairs|last=Hert|first=Paul|last2=Papakonstantinou|first2=Vagelis|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
==Connection to international relations== The regulatory differences in the protection of personal data between countries has real impact on international relations. The right to be forgotten, specifically, is a matter of EU-US relations when applied to cross-border data flow, as it raises questions about territorial sovereignty. The structure of the [[Westphalian sovereignty|Westphalian international system]] assumes that the reach of a country's jurisdiction is limited to its geographic territory.<ref name="Stephen J. Kobrin 2004 pp 111-131">{{cite journal | last1 = Kobrin | first1 = Stephen J. | year = 2004 | title = Safe harbours are hard to find: the trans-Atlantic data privacy dispute, territorial jurisdiction and global governance | url = | journal = Review of International Studies | volume = 30 | issue = | pages = 111–131 | doi = 10.1017/S0260210504005856 }}</ref> However, online interactions are independent of geographic location and present across multiple locations, rendering the traditional concept of territorial sovereignty moot.<ref name="Stephen J. Kobrin 2004 pp 111-131"/> Therefore, the EU and the United States are forced to confront their regulatory differences and negotiate on a set of regulations that apply to all foreign companies processing and handling data of European citizens and residents.<ref name="Stephen J. Kobrin 2004 pp 111-131"/>
The regulatory differences on the right to be forgotten along with numerous other data protection rights have shaped discussions and negotiations on trans-Atlantic data privacy regulations. A case in point is the EU and the United States' endeavors to develop the [[International Safe Harbor Privacy Principles|Safe Harbor]] agreement, a data transfer pact that enables the transfer of data between the EU and US companies in a manner consistent with the EU's data protection schemes.<ref name="ReferenceC">The Council: Common Position (EC) no. 95</ref> Article 25 of the Data Protection Directive articulates that cross-border transfer of data can take place only if the "third country in question ensures an adequate level of protection," meaning that the country meets the EU's minimum standards of data protection.<ref name="ReferenceC"/> The standards include, among many provisions, a component that protects the right to "opt out" of further processing or transmission of personal data, under the assumption that data may not be further processed in ways inconsistent with the intent for which they were collected.<ref name="ReferenceC"/>
Given the inconsistencies between the EU and the United States on numerous [[digital privacy]] regulations, including the right to be forgotten, Article 25 poses a threat to trans-Atlantic data flows. Therefore, the EU and the United States entered into negotiations to mediate the differences through the Safe Harbor agreement, which as a result of debate and discussion between the two parties, requires companies to provide individuals with the choice or opportunity to "opt out" and afford other protections.<ref name="ReferenceC"/>
Under the pressures of the mass surveillance carried out by the US government on European citizens' data, the Safe Harbor agreement has been invalidated by the [[European_Court_of_Justice|European Union Court of Justice]] in its [[Max Schrems|''Schrems'' case.]] The Safe Harbor agreement has now been replaced by the [[EU-US_Privacy_Shield|Privacy Shield principles]].
==Draft European Data Protection Regulation==<!-- do not decapitalise; this is a proper noun --> {{main|General Data Protection Regulation}} {{outofdate|section|date=February 2018}} The 2012 draft European Data Protection Regulation Article 17 detailed the "right to be forgotten and to erasure".<ref name="europa1">{{Citation |year=2012 |title=Proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the protection of individuals with regard to the processing of personal data and on the free movement of such data (General Data Protection Regulation) |at=Article 17 "Right to be forgotten and to erasure" |publisher=European Commission |url=http://ec.europa.eu/justice/data-protection/document/review2012/com_2012_11_en.pdf |format=PDF}}</ref> Under Article 17 individuals to whom the data appertains are granted the right to "obtain from the controller the erasure of personal data relating to them and the abstention from further dissemination of such data, especially in relation to personal data which are made available by the data subject while he or she was a child or where the data is no longer necessary for the purpose it was collected for, the subject withdraws consent, the storage period has expired, the data subject objects to the processing of personal data or the processing of data does not comply with other regulation".<ref name="europa1"/>
The EU defines "data controllers" as "people or bodies that collect and manage personal data".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/justice/data-protection/data-collection/index_en.htm |title=Who can collect and process personal data? - Justice |publisher=Ec.europa.eu |date=2014-06-26 |accessdate=2014-08-09}}</ref> The EU General Data Protection Regulation requires data controllers who have been informed that an individual has requested the deletion of any links to or copies of information must "take all reasonable steps, including technical measures, in relation to data for the publication of which the controller is responsible, to inform third parties which are processing such data, that a data subject requests them to erase any links to, or copy or replication of that personal data. Where the controller has authorized a third party publication of personal data, the controller shall be considered responsible for that publication".<ref name="europa1"/> In the situation that a data controller does not take all reasonable steps then they will be fined heavily.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.out-law.com/en/articles/2014/march/european-parliament-gives-overwhelming-backing-to-new-eu-data-protection-laws/ |title=European Parliament gives overwhelming backing to new EU data protection laws |publisher=Out-law.com |date=March 12, 2014 |accessdate=2014-08-09}}</ref>
The European Parliament was once "expected to adopt the proposals in first reading in the April 2013 Plenary session".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://europa.eu/rapid/press-release_MEMO-14-60_en.htm |title=EUROPA - Press Releases - Press release - Data Protection Day 2014: Full Speed on EU Data Protection Reform |publisher=Europa.eu |date=January 27, 2014 |accessdate=2014-08-09}}</ref> The right to be forgotten was replaced by a more limited right to erasure in the version of the GDPR adopted by the European Parliament in March 2014.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Baldry|first1=Tony|authorlink=Tony Baldry|last2=Hyams|first2=Oliver|title=The Right to Be Forgotten|url=http://1essexcourt.wordpress.com/2014/05/15/the-right-to-be-forgotten/|publisher=1 Essex Court}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=European Parliament legislative resolution of 12 March 2014 on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the protection of individuals with regard to the processing of personal data and on the free movement of such data (General Data Protection Regulation)|url=http://www.europarl.europa.eu/sides/getDoc.do?type=TA&reference=P7-TA-2014-0212&language=EN|publisher=[[European Parliament]]}}</ref> Article 17 provides that the data subject has the right to request erasure of personal data related to him on any one of a number of grounds including non-compliance with article 6.1 (lawfulness) that includes a case (f) where the legitimate interests of the controller is overridden by the interests or fundamental rights and freedoms of the data subject which require protection of personal data (see also [[Google Spain v AEPD and Mario Costeja González|Costeja]]).<ref>{{cite news|last1=Powles|first1=Julia|title=What did the media miss with the 'right to be forgotten' coverage?|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2014/may/21/what-did-the-media-miss-with-the-right-to-be-forgotten-coverage|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=21 May 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Factsheet on the 'Right to be Forgotten' ruling (case C-131/12)|url=http://ec.europa.eu/justice/data-protection/files/factsheets/factsheet_data_protection_en.pdf|publisher=[[European Commission]]}}</ref>
The European Union is a highly influential group of states, and this movement towards the right to be forgotten in the EU is a step towards its global recognition as a right. To support this, in 2012 the Obama Administration released a "Privacy Bill of Rights" to protect consumers online, and while this is not quite the strength of the EU law, it is a step towards recognition of the right to be forgotten.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2012/02/23/fact-sheet-plan-protect-privacy-internet-age-adopting-consumer-privacy-b |title=Fact Sheet: Plan to Protect Privacy in the Internet Age by Adopting a Consumer Privacy Bill of Rights | The White House |publisher=Whitehouse.gov |date=2012-02-23 |accessdate=2014-08-09}}</ref>
==Response by Reputation Management Firms==
Businesses that manage their client's online reputation have responded to the European Court ruling by excercising the right to be forgotten as a means to remove unfavourable information.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://searchengineland.com/reputation-vip-online-management-firm-launches-site-assist-googles-forget-form-194998|title=The Inevitable Happened: First Company Provides "Right To Be Forgotten" Removal Service|date=2014-06-25|work=Search Engine Land|access-date=2017-03-03|language=en-US}}</ref> One technique used by reputation consulting firms is to submit multiple requests for each link, written with different angles in an attempt to get links removed. Google for example does not limit the number of requests that can be submitted on the removal of a given link.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/07/09/technology/european-companies-see-opportunity-in-the-right-to-be-forgotten.html|title=European Companies See Opportunity in the 'Right to Be Forgotten'|last=Scott|first=Mark|date=2014-07-08|work=The New York Times|access-date=2017-03-03|issn=0362-4331}}</ref>
==Criticism== {{outofdate|section|reason=the General Data Protection Regulation is no longer in draft|date=February 2018}} Major criticisms stem from the idea that the right to be forgotten would restrict the right to freedom of speech.<ref>{{cite journal |authorlink=Eugene Volokh |last=Volokh |first=Eugene |title=Freedom of Speech, Information Privacy, and the Troubling Implications of a Right to Stop People from Speaking about You |year=2000 |journal=[[Stanford Law Review]] |volume=52 |issue=5 |pages=1049–1124 |doi=10.2307/1229510 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |authorlink=Daniel J. Solove |last=Solove |first=Daniel J. |title=The Virtues of Knowing Less: Justifying Privacy Protections against Disclosure |year=2003 |volume=53 |journal=[[Duke Law Journal]] |issue=3 |pages=967–1065 [p. 976] |jstor=1373222 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Mayes |first=Tessa |title=We have no right to be forgotten online |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |date=18 March 2011 |url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/libertycentral/2011/mar/18/forgotten-online-european-union-law-internet }}</ref> Many nations, and the United States in particular (with the [[First Amendment to the United States Constitution]]), have very strong domestic [[freedom of speech]] law, which would be challenging to reconcile with the right to be forgotten.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Whitman |first=James Q. |title=The Two Western Cultures of Privacy: Dignity Versus Liberty |year=2004 |volume=113 |journal=[[Yale Law Journal]] |issue=6 |pages=1151–1221 [p. 1161–2] |jstor=4135723 }}</ref> Some academics see that only a limited form of the right to be forgotten would be reconcilable with US constitutional law; the right of an individual to delete data that he or she has personally submitted.<ref name="theatlantic1"/><ref name="walker"/><ref>{{cite web| last=Ryan |first=Timothy |url=http://www.psfk.com/2011/05/the-right-to-be-forgotten-questioning-the-nature-of-online-privacy.html |title=The Right To Be Forgotten: Questioning The Nature Of Online Privacy |publisher=PSFK |date=2011-05-02 |accessdate=2014-08-09}}</ref> In this limited form of the right individuals could not have material removed that has been uploaded by others, as demanding the removal of information could constitute [[censorship]] and a reduction in the freedom of expression in many countries.<ref>{{cite journal |year=2011 |last=Bernal |first=Paul Alexander |title=A right to delete? |journal=European Journal of Law and Technology |volume=2 |issue=2 |pages= |doi= |url=http://ejlt.org/article/view/75/144 }}</ref> Sandra Coliver of the [[Open Society Justice Initiative]] argues that not all rights must be compatible and this conflict between the two rights is not detrimental to the survival of either.<ref>Coliver, Sandra. Editor. "Striking a Balance. Hate Speech, Freedom of Expression and Non-Discrimination." Article 19. (1992) International Centre against Censorship. Human Rights Centre. University of Essex.</ref>
The draft General Data Protection Regulation was written broadly and this has caused concern.<ref name="fleischer"/> It has attracted criticism that its enactment would require data controlling companies to go to great lengths to identify third parties with the information and remove it.<ref name="stanfordlawreview1">{{cite web|url=http://www.stanfordlawreview.org/online/privacy-paradox/right-to-be-forgotten |title=The Right to Be Forgotten |last=Rosen |first=Jeffrey |publisher=Stanford Law Review |volume=64 |issue=88 |date= February 13, 2012 |accessdate=2014-08-09}}</ref> The proposed regulation has also attracted criticism due to the fact that this could produce a censoring effect in that companies, such as Facebook or Google, will wish to not be fined under the act, and will therefore be likely to delete wholesale information rather than facing the fine, which could produce a "serious chilling effect."<ref name=" stanfordlawreview1"/> In addition to this, there are concerns about the requirement to take down information that others have posted about an individual; the definition of personal data in Article 4(2) includes "any information relating to" the individual.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/TXT/?uri=CELEX:52012PC0011 |title=Document 52012PC0011 — Proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the protection of individuals with regard to the processing of personal data and on the free movement of such data (General Data Protection Regulation) |publisher=Eur-lex.europa.eu |at=3.4.1. Chapter I - General Provisions, Article 4 |accessdate=2014-08-09}}</ref> This, critics have claimed, would require companies to take down any information relating to an individual, regardless of its source, which would amount to censorship, and result in the big data companies eradicating a lot of data to comply with this.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.economist.com/node/21543489 |title=Privacy laws: Private data, public rules |publisher=The Economist |date=2012-01-28 |accessdate=2014-08-09}}</ref> Such removal can impact the accuracy and ability of businesses and individuals to carry out [[business intelligence]], particularly [[due diligence]] to comply with antibribery, anticorruption, and [[know your customer]] laws.<ref name="WSJ impact on business intelligence">{{cite news|last1=Wright|first1=Jason|title=Some Things Should Not Be 'Forgotten'|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/jason-wright-some-things-should-not-be-forgotten-1421689011|accessdate=16 February 2015|work=The Wall Street Journal|date=19 January 2015|subscription=yes|quote=Consider the necessity for accurate business intelligence. Antibribery laws and "know your customer" regulations often require companies and individuals to do due-diligence checks on entities they want to do business with… The requirement for proper due diligence instils confidence, helps to prevent fraud and corruption, and informs businesses about potential risks… Several cases already illustrate how the "right to be forgotten" impedes business intelligence. Fortune magazine reported last year on Dato Capital, a company that compiles reports on the directors of private companies based in the United Kingdom and Spain… Dato's reports contained information that companies and directors are often required by law to disclose publicly, such as debt and financial history. Bleaching this from search results has made it more difficult for potential investors and business partners to understand the profile and history of individuals with whom they were considering doing business.}}</ref> The right to be forgotten was invoked to remove from Google searches 120 reports about company directors published by [[Dato Capital]], a Spanish company which compiles such reports about private company directors, consisting entirely of information they are required by law to disclose;<ref name="WSJ impact on business intelligence" /><ref name="Fortune business director reports removed" /> ''[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]]'' magazine examined the 64 reports relating to UK directorships, finding that in 27 (42%) the director was the only person named, in the remaining only the director and co-directors were named, and 23 (36%) involve directorships started since 2012.<ref name="Fortune business director reports removed">{{cite news|last1=Parloff|first1=Roger|title=Company directors are deep-sixing Google links citing 'right to be forgotten'|url=http://fortune.com/2014/10/21/company-directors-deep-sixing-google-links/|accessdate=17 February 2015|work=Fortune|date=21 October 2014}}</ref>
Other criticism revolves around the principle of [[accountability]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Zittrain|first1=Jonathan|title=The right to be forgotten ruling leaves nagging doubts|url=http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/c5d17a80-0910-11e4-8d27-00144feab7de.html#axzz3gL6XFlzC|accessdate=19 July 2015|publisher=[[Financial Times]]|date=13 July 2014}}</ref>
There were concerns that the proposed General Data Protection Regulation would result in [[Google]] and other Internet search engines not producing neutral search results, but rather producing biased and patchy results, and compromising the [[integrity]] of Internet-based information.<ref name="stanfordlawreview1"/> To balance out this criticism, the proposed General Data Protection Regulation included an exception "for the processing of personal data carried out solely for journalistic purposes or the purpose of artistic or literary expression in order to reconcile the right to the protection of personal data with the rules governing freedom of expression."<ref name="europa1"/> Article 80 upheld freedom of speech, and while not lessening obligations on data providers and social media sites, nevertheless due to the wide meaning of "journalistic purposes" allows more autonomy and reduces the amount of information that is necessary to be removed.<ref name="mantelero"/>{{rp|9}} When Google agreed to implement the ruling, European Commission Vice-President [[Viviane Reding]] said, "The Court also made clear that journalistic work must not be touched; it is to be protected."<ref>{{cite press release | url=http://ec.europa.eu/justice/newsroom/data-protection/news/140602_en.htm | title='Right to be forgotten' and online search engines ruling | publisher=European Commission | date=2014-06-03 | accessdate=2014-07-03}}</ref> However, Google was criticized for taking down (under the Costeja precedent) a BBC News blog post about [[Stan O'Neal]] by economics editor [[Robert Peston]] (eventually, Peston reported that his blog post has remained findable in Google after all).<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.bbc.com/news/business-28130581 | title=Why has Google cast me into oblivion? | work=BBC News | date=2 July 2014 | accessdate=2014-07-03 | author=Peston, Robert}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.truthdig.com/eartotheground/item/the_right_to_be_forgotten_is_already_messing_up_journalism_20140702 | title=The 'Right to Be Forgotten' Is Already Messing Up Journalism | work=Truthdig | date=July 2, 2014 | accessdate=2014-07-03 | author=Scheer, Peter Z.}}</ref> Despite these criticisms and Google's action, the company's CEO, [[Larry Page]] worries that the ruling will be "used by other governments that aren't as forward and progressive as Europe to do bad things", though has since distanced himself from that position.<ref name="theguardian.com">{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2014/jul/24/google-hauled-in-by-europe-over-right-to-be-forgotten-reaction|title=Google hauled in by Europe over 'right to be forgotten' reaction|author=Samuel Gibbs|work=the Guardian}}</ref> For example, pianist [[Dejan Lazic]] cited the ''Right To Be Forgotten'' in trying to remove a negative review about his performance from ''[[The Washington Post]]''. He claimed that the critique was "defamatory, mean-spirited, opionated, offensive and simply irrelevant for the arts".<ref>{{cite web|title=Musician attempts use EU Right To Be Forgotten to hide a bad review|url=http://eurighttobeforgotten.com/musician-attempts-use-eu-right-forgotten-hide-bad-review/|accessdate=11 November 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Dewey|first1=Caitlin|title=Pianist asks The Washington Post to remove a concert review under the E.U.'s 'right to be forgotten' ruling|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-intersect/wp/2014/10/31/pianist-asks-the-washington-post-to-remove-a-concert-review-under-the-e-u-s-right-to-be-forgotten-ruling/|work=The Washington Post|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6U3fWhpLk|archivedate=13 November 2014|deadurl=no}}</ref> and the St. Lawrence parish of the Roman Catholic church in Kutno, Poland asked Google to remove [[:pl:Parafia św. Wawrzyńca w Kutnie|the Polish Wikipedia page about it]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://m.wikimediafoundation.org/wiki/Notices_received_from_search_engines#/image/File:Pl1RTBF.pdf|title=Notice of removal from Google Search|last=Google|publisher=WikiMedia Foundation|accessdate=23 November 2014}}</ref> {{pl icon}} without any allegations mentioned therein as of that date.
[[Index on Censorship]] claimed that the ''Costeja'' ruling "allows individuals to complain to search engines about information they do not like with no legal oversight. This is akin to marching into a library and forcing it to pulp books. Although the ruling is intended for private individuals it opens the door to anyone who wants to whitewash their personal history… The Court's decision is a retrograde move that misunderstands the role and responsibility of search engines and the wider internet. It should send chills down the spine of everyone in the European Union who believes in the crucial importance of free expression and freedom of information."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.indexoncensorship.org/2014/05/index-blasts-eu-court-ruling-right-forgotten/ |title=Index blasts EU court ruling on "right to be forgotten" |publisher=Index on Censorship |date=2014-05-13 |accessdate=2014-08-09}}</ref>
In 2014, the [[Gerry Hutch]] page on the [[English Wikipedia]] was among the first [[Wikipedia]] pages to be removed by several [[search engine]]s' query results in the [[European Union]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Chubb |first1=Karla |title=Request made to remove Gerry 'The Monk' Hutch from EU search results |url=http://www.newstalk.ie/Gerry-The-Monk-Hutch-one-of-first-to-request-removal-of-Wikipedia-page |accessdate=6 August 2014 |publisher=Newstalk}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Curties |first1=Sophie |last2=Philipson |first2=Alice |title=Wikipedia founder: EU's Right to be Forgotten is 'deeply immoral' |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/technology/wikipedia/11015901/EU-ruling-on-link-removal-deeply-immoral-says-Wikipedia-founder.html |accessdate=6 August 2014 |publisher=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |date=6 August 2014}}</ref> ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' said, on 6 Aug 2014, that Wikipedia co-founder [[Jimmy Wales]] "described the EU's Right to be Forgotten as deeply immoral, as the organisation that operates the online encyclopedia warned the ruling will result in an internet riddled with [[memory hole]]s".<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/technology/wikipedia/11015901/EU-ruling-on-link-removal-deeply-immoral-says-Wikipedia-founder.html | title=Wikipedia founder: EU's Right to be Forgotten is 'deeply immoral' | publisher=The Telegraph | date=6 Aug 2014 | accessdate=7 August 2014}}</ref> Other commentators have disagreed with Wales, pointing to problems such as Google including links to [[revenge porn]] sites in its search results,<ref name=Arthur/><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2014/jul/29/revenge-porn-right-to-be-forgotten-house-of-lords |last=Edwards |first=Lilian |title=Revenge porn: why the right to be forgotten is the right remedy |work=The Guardian |date=29 July 2014 |accessdate=11 August 2014}}</ref> and have accused Google of orchestrating a publicity campaign to escape the burdensome obligation to comply with the law.<ref name=whydoit/><ref name=grasp/> Julia Powles, a law and technology researcher at the [[University of Cambridge]], made a rebuttal to Wales' and the [[Wikimedia Foundation]] concerns in an editorial published by ''Guardian'', opining that "There is a public sphere of memory and truth, and there is a private one...Without the freedom to be private, we have precious little freedom at all."<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2014/aug/08/jimmy-wales-right-to-be-forgotten-wikipedia |title=Jimmy Wales is wrong: we do have a personal right to be forgotten |last=Powles |first=Julia |work=The Guardian|date=8 August 2014|accessdate=11 August 2014}}</ref>
In response to the criticism, the EU has released a factsheet to address what it considers myths about the right to be forgotten.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://web.archive.org/web/20140924080430/ec.europa.eu/justice/newsroom/data-protection/news/140918_en.htm|title = Mythbuster: The Court of Justice of the EU and the "Right to be Forgotten"|website = European Commission's Directorate General for Justice and Consumers, via archive.org |date=18 September 2014 |accessdate=5 November 2018}}</ref>
Other criticisms involving the right to be forgotten revolves around the policies for data removal regarding minors. The U.S. has laws in place that protect the privacy of minors. The California Minor Eraser Law is a law that allows California residents under the age of 18 to request to have information removed that they posted on an online server. The law "applies to websites, social media sites, mobile apps and other online services"<ref name=":9">{{Cite news|url=http://www.dataprotectionreport.com/2015/01/california-enacts-right-to-be-forgotten-for-minors/|title=California enacts "Right to be Forgotten" for Minors - Data Protection Report|date=2015-01-14|work=Data Protection Report|access-date=2017-05-31|language=en-US}}</ref> and follows "Europe's recognition of the 'right to be forgotten'".<ref name=":9" /> This law was put into effect on January 1, 2015 and remains in existence today. Online "service"<ref name=":10">{{Cite web|url=http://www.lexology.com/library/detail.aspx?g=5c1e37a5-3b96-4b52-84df-5b5c89a4f2f7|title=Get to Know California's 'Online Eraser' Law {{!}} Lexology|last=Lewis|first=Morgan|last2=Kapoor|first2=Bockius LLP-Rahul|access-date=2017-05-31|last3=Hirsch|first3=W. Reece|last4=Yaghoubi|first4=Shokoh H.}}</ref> operators that have services "directed toward minors"<ref name=":10" /> must update their privacy policies to include the option to remove data if requested by a minor that is posted on a service.
In the UK, the [[United Kingdom general election, 2017|2017]] [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]] manifesto<ref name=":11">{{Cite web|url=http://diginomica.com/2017/05/15/election-2017-tories-offer-18s-right-forgotten-threaten-big-fines-social-media-firms/|title=UK Election 2017 - Tories offer under-18s the Right to be Forgotten, threaten big fines for social media firms|date=2017-05-15|website=diginomica|access-date=2017-05-31}}</ref> included a pledge to allow social media platform users to remove outdated information that was posted when they were under the age of 18. "A Tory victory on the 8th of June will lead to those youthful indiscretions on Facebook and Twitter being open to erasure. But there are also plans to fine social media firms for not moving at the speed of political opportunism over extreme content."<ref name=":11" /> The United Kingdom has not yet fully adopted the ruling of the [[European Court of Justice]] regarding the right to be forgotten and argued to keep it from going into EU law.{{fact|date=February 2018}} However, in the upcoming elections in the UK laws could be passed to allow minors to remove embarrassing posts or photos on social media that could come back to affect job applications or public image in later life.
[[Theresa May]], the Prime Minister of the UK, has been pushing to extend privacy rights for minors in allowing them to have a right to delete information. The intentions for this extension of privacy are based on the fact that social media sites store years of data that affect minors lives' much later after the information is posted.<ref name=":12">{{Cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/politics/articles/2017-05-12/may-tells-facebook-to-offer-kids-right-to-delete-information|title=May Tells Facebook to Offer Kids the Right to Delete Information|date=2017-05-12|work=Bloomberg.com|access-date=2017-05-31}}</ref> May gave her stance on privacy when she said, "'The Internet has brought a wealth of opportunity but also significant new risks which have evolved faster than society's response to them'".<ref name=":12" /> The [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]], which is headed by May, has pushed for policies that aggressively removes illegal material from the internet and fines firms that do not take action in removing said material.<ref name=":12" />
In 2015, [[Commission nationale de l'informatique et des libertés]] (CNIL), the data privacy watchdog of France trird to impose the right globally. CNIL asked [[Google]] to remove data from all versions available in any part of the world. Google and other entities argued that European data regulators should not be allowed to decide what Internet users around the world find when they use a search engine.<ref> [https://previewtech.net/right-to-be-forgotten-globally-google-cnil-france/ France tries to impose ‘Right to be Forgotten’ globally. Google fights ]</ref>
==Research== [[File:Oblivion Framework Architecture new.png|thumb|right|Conceptual overview of Oblivion]] Security researchers from CISPA, Saarland University<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://cispa.saarland|title = CISPA: The Center for IT-Security, Privacy, and Accountability}}</ref> and the University of Auckland<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.cs.auckland.ac.nz/en.html|title = The University of Auckland}}</ref> proposed a framework, called Oblivion,<ref>{{cite arXiv |last=Simeonovski |first=Milivoj | last2=Bendun |first2=Fabian |last3=Asghar |first3=Muhammad Rizwan | last4=Backes |first4=Michael| last5=Marnau |first5=Ninja |last6=Druschel |first6=Peter | eprint=1506.06033 |title=Oblivion: Mitigating Privacy Leaks by Controlling the Discoverability of Online Information |date=2015}}</ref> to support the automation of the right to be forgotten in a scalable, provable and privacy-preserving manner. Oblivion is a program that helps to "automate" the process of attempting to verify someone's personal information that could be found in a Google search result."<ref name=":3">{{Cite web | url = http://motherboard.vice.com/read/oblivion-is-the-software-that-could-automate-the-right-to-be-forgotten | title = 'Oblivion' Is the Software That Could Automate the 'Right to Be Forgotten' | website = Motherboard | language = en-us | access-date = 2016-02-29 }}</ref> Google gets many take-down requests at a high volume, so Oblivion is able to help with this problem. Researchers and authors behind Oblivion say that "it is essential to develop techniques that at least partly automate this process and are scalable to internet size."<ref name=":3" /> Oblivion helps the humans that operate the forms at Google ensure that ill-intending users cannot "blacklist links to internet sources that do not affect them."<ref name=":3" /> For example, tests have proven that Oblivion handles requests at a rate of 278 per second.<ref name=":3" /> The software allows Google, the government, and the user to work together to get content removed quickly and for just cause. In order to ensure that the program works quickly, is secure for its users and is impervious to fake take-down requests, Oblivion uses a three-part system.
In the first part, Oblivion requires a user to submit identification about themselves – not limited to "name, age, and nationality."<ref name=":3" /> Oblivion then enables a user to automatically find and tag his or her disseminated personal information using natural language processing and image recognition techniques and file a request in a privacy-preserving manner. Oblivion will scan the article for attributes that match information that has been submitted by the user. Second, Oblivion provides indexing systems with an automated and provable eligibility mechanism, asserting that the author of a request is indeed affected by an online resource. The author of a request is then issued an "ownership token"<ref name=":3" /> that confirms the articles they submitted for evaluation include sensitive personal information. The automated eligibility proof ensures censorship-resistance so that only legitimately affected individuals can request the removal of corresponding links from search results. In the third and last phase, this "ownership token" is submitted to Google, accompanied by the user's concerns as to what information should be deleted.<ref name=":3" /> Google's staff is then allowed to decide for themselves if they want to delete this information or not - but thanks to Oblivion, they know that the information in question is valid.
Researchers with Oblivion, however, have noted that it comes with some limitations. The software is lacking a human element, therefore it cannot decide on its own "whether or not a piece of information is public interest and should therefore not be removed from Google search results."<ref name=":3" /> Researchers have conducted comprehensive evaluations, showing that Oblivion is suitable for large-scale deployment once it is fine-tuned.{{Citation needed|date=August 2016}}
